claim: Per capita income is higher in the US than in Japan on average.

supporting.text: The nominal GDP per capita of the United States is higher than that of Japan, as reported by the World Bank and IMF.

attacks.text: The nominal GDP per capita of the United States is higher than that of Japan, as reported by the World Bank and IMF.
Nominal GDP per capita does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in the US than in Japan.
Even adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), the US GDP per capita remains higher than Japan's, according to World Bank data.
The reported GDP per capita figures may not reflect income inequality, which could mean median income is more comparable between the two countries.
Median income data from OECD shows that US median income is still higher than Japan's, supporting the original claim.

supporting.text: Median household income in the US exceeds that of Japan, based on OECD statistics.

attacks.text: Median household income in the US exceeds that of Japan, based on OECD statistics.
Median household income does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in the US than in Japan.
OECD statistics adjust for purchasing power parity (PPP), which accounts for cost of living differences, making the comparison valid.
Median income ignores wealth inequality, and the US has higher income inequality than Japan, which may skew the perception of average prosperity.
While inequality is higher in the US, median income still represents the middle of the distribution and is a robust measure for comparing typical households.

supporting.text: The US has a higher average wage for full-time workers compared to Japan, according to labor market data.

attacks.text: The US has a higher average wage for full-time workers compared to Japan, according to labor market data.
Average wage does not account for differences in cost of living, which is significantly higher in the US than in Japan.
Cost of living adjustments are already factored into per capita income calculations, making the US still higher in real terms.
The data on full-time workers excludes part-time and gig economy workers, where Japan has a larger proportion of such employment.
Even including part-time workers, the US maintains a higher median income due to higher wage floors in many sectors.
Japan has more comprehensive social benefits and lower healthcare costs, which effectively increase disposable income.
Per capita income metrics typically exclude non-monetary benefits, so social benefits do not negate the higher monetary income in the US.

supporting.text: Japan's aging population and stagnant wage growth contribute to lower per capita income relative to the US.

attacks.text: Japan's aging population and stagnant wage growth contribute to lower per capita income relative to the US.
Japan's high savings rate and wealth accumulation among older generations offset lower income growth, making per capita wealth comparable.
Wealth accumulation does not directly translate to income, and Japan's deflationary pressures still suppress per capita income figures.
The US has higher income inequality, so median per capita income may not be as favorable as the average suggests.
Even accounting for inequality, the US median per capita income remains significantly higher than Japan's due to broader economic dynamism.

supporting.text: The US economy's higher productivity and innovation-driven sectors result in greater income generation per capita than Japan.

attacks.text: The US economy's higher productivity and innovation-driven sectors result in greater income generation per capita than Japan.
Japan's income distribution is more equitable, reducing the impact of outliers that skew per capita income in the US.
The US has a higher Gini coefficient, indicating greater income inequality, which means per capita income may not reflect median income accurately.
Japan's aging population and lower labor force participation rate reduce its per capita income compared to the US.
Japan's high savings rate and asset wealth compensate for lower income figures, improving actual living standards.
The US benefits from a larger domestic market and global economic influence, driving higher per capita income.
Japan's strong export economy and trade surplus contribute significantly to national wealth, offsetting lower per capita income.

supporting.text: Currency exchange rates (USD/JPY) historically favor the US dollar, further widening the per capita income gap when measured in USD.

attacks.text: Currency exchange rates (USD/JPY) historically favor the US dollar, further widening the per capita income gap when measured in USD.
Exchange rate fluctuations are temporary and do not reflect real purchasing power parity (PPP), which adjusts for cost of living differences.
Even when adjusted for PPP, US per capita income remains higher due to structural economic advantages like productivity and innovation.
Japan's lower income inequality means median disposable income is more comparable to the US than per capita averages suggest.
US median income still exceeds Japan's after adjusting for inequality, as the GDP per capita gap is too large to offset.
